items.question: The Glorious Revolution's most significant constitutional outcome was:
options: B) Establishment of parliamentary sovereignty over the Crown
D) Divine right of kings reinforcement

items.question: The Bill of Rights (1689) differed from Magna Carta (1215) primarily in:
options: A) Both limited royal power equally
B) Bill of Rights established parliamentary supremacy while Magna Carta protected baronial privileges
C) Magna Carta was more comprehensive

items.question: The Hanoverian Succession (1714) was necessary because:
options: A) Queen Anne died without Protestant heirs

items.question: The Act of Settlement (1701) primarily aimed to:
options: B) Ensure Protestant succession to the throne

items.question: The significance of the Glorious Revolution for American colonists was:
options: A) It had no impact on colonies
B) It established precedent for resistance to arbitrary rule

items.question: The Whig interpretation of history viewed the Glorious Revolution as:
options: B) The inevitable triumph of liberty and parliamentary democracy

items.question: The financial settlement after 1689 gave Parliament control through:
options: A) Complete abolition of royal income
B) Annual approval of military budgets
D) Creating the Bank of England immediately

items.question: The Triennial Act (1694) was significant because it:
options: A) Required Parliament to meet every three years
B) Limited monarchs to three-year reigns
C) Created three houses of Parliament

items.question: James II's downfall was primarily due to:
options: B) Combination of Catholic policies and birth of Catholic heir

items.question: The Convention Parliament of 1689 was unique because:
options: B) It was summoned without royal writ

items.question: The Industrial Revolution began in Britain rather than elsewhere primarily due to:
options: B) Combination of capital, coal, colonies, and political stability

items.question: The social impact of industrialization included all EXCEPT:
The Factory Acts were passed primarily because:
options: B) Public outcry over child labor conditions

items.question: The relationship between the Agricultural and Industrial Revolutions was:
options: B) Agricultural changes freed labor and capital for industry

items.question: The "Condition of England" question in the 1840s referred to:
options: B) Social problems created by industrialization

items.question: Engels and Marx studied Manchester because it:
The Great Exhibition of 1851 demonstrated:
Railway development's most significant impact was:
options: B) Integration of national markets and transformation of time consciousness

items.question: The "workshop of the world" concept meant Britain:
options: B) Dominated global manufacturing and trade

items.question: Industrial cities' growth created new challenges including:
options: B) Public health crises, class tensions, and governance issues

items.question: The Reform Act of 1832 was revolutionary because it:
options: B) Broke the principle that Parliament could reform itself

items.question: Gladstone and Disraeli's rivalry represented:
options: B) Competing visions of Britain's future and role

items.question: The concept of "One Nation Conservatism" associated with Disraeli meant:
options: B) Bridging class divisions through paternalistic reform

items.question: Gladstone's approach to Ireland failed primarily because:
options: B) He underestimated Protestant Unionist resistance

items.question: The Whig oligarchy (1714-1760) maintained power through:
options: B) Patronage, corruption, and management of Parliament

items.question: George III's "personal rule" attempts failed because:
options: B) Constitutional conventions had shifted power to Parliament

items.question: The rise of party politics in the 18th century reflected:
options: B) Need to manage parliamentary majorities and patronage

items.question: Peel's Conservative Party differed from old Tories by:
options: B) Accepting need for gradual reform to preserve stability

items.question: The Parliament Act of 1911 was triggered by:
options: B) Lords' rejection of Liberal budget

items.question: The emergence of Labour replaced the Liberals primarily due to:
options: B) Structural changes in class politics and franchise extension

items.question: The transition from Empire to Commonwealth reflected:
options: B) Accommodation to nationalist movements and changed power realities

items.question: The loss of American colonies (1776-1783) led Britain to:
options: B) Shift focus to India and second empire

items.question: The "White Man's Burden" concept justified imperialism through:
options: B) Civilizing mission ideology combining race, religion, and progress

items.question: Indian independence in 1947 was hastened by:
options: B) World War II's impact and nationalist pressure

items.question: The Suez Crisis (1956) marked:
options: B) End of Britain's independent great power status

items.question: Decolonization accelerated after 1945 due to:
options: B) Economic exhaustion, changed values, and international pressure

items.question: The Commonwealth differs from Empire in being:
The Balfour Declaration (1926) established:
The economic impact of empire on Britain included:
options: B) Both wealth extraction and defense/administration costs

items.question: Post-colonial immigration to Britain created:
options: B) Multicultural society and identity questions

items.question: Britain's entry into WWI was triggered by:
The "Eastern Question" persisted because:
options: B) Ottoman decline created power vacuum affecting European balance

items.question: Splendid Isolation ended because:
options: B) German naval and economic challenge required allies

items.question: The Crimean War's significance lay in:
Appeasement policy of the 1930s reflected:
options: B) War trauma, strategic overstretch, and ideological factors

items.question: The Battle of Britain's importance was:
options: B) Preventing German invasion and maintaining resistance base

items.question: The Falklands War's political impact included:
options: B) Thatcher's strengthened position and national confidence

items.question: Post-WWII foreign policy shifted toward:
options: B) Atlantic alliance and European integration

items.question: The Special Relationship with America reflected:
options: B) Britain's need for support in reduced circumstances

items.question: Britain's nuclear deterrent represented:
options: B) Attempt to maintain great power status

items.question: The Chartist movement failed because:
options: B) Economic improvement, internal divisions, and middle-class opposition

items.question: Women's suffrage succeeded through:
options: B) Combination of militant tactics, war service, and changing attitudes

items.question: The welfare state's creation reflected:
options: B) Wartime solidarity and consensus on social reform

items.question: Trade union development was shaped by:
options: B) Industrialization, legal struggles, and political action

items.question: The Poor Law Amendment Act (1834) was controversial because:
options: B) Harsh workhouse conditions violated traditional relief

items.question: Methodist revival's social impact included:
options: B) Working-class organization and moral reform

items.question: The Fabian Society's significance was:
options: B) Intellectual foundation for democratic socialism

items.question: Victorian philanthropy reflected:
options: B) Mixture of genuine concern and social control

items.question: Education reform proceeded slowly because:
options: B) Religious conflicts and class interests

items.question: Public health improvements required:
options: B) State intervention overcoming laissez-faire ideology

items.question: The Corn Law repeal (1846) signified:
options: B) Victory of free trade and industrial over landed interests

items.question: Britain's economic decline from the 1870s resulted from:
options: B) Foreign competition, technological lag, and investment patterns

items.question: The Gold Standard's abandonment (1931) marked:
options: B) End of sterling's global dominance

items.question: Nationalization post-1945 aimed to:
options: B) Modernize key industries and ensure full employment

items.question: Thatcherism's economic philosophy emphasized:
options: B) Monetarism, privatization, and market forces

items.question: The City of London's importance reflected:
options: B) Historical financial expertise and global connections

items.question: Deindustrialization's social impact included:
options: B) Regional decline and community destruction

items.question: North Sea oil's discovery affected:
options: B) Balance of payments and political economy

items.question: EU membership's economic impact was:
options: B) Mixed, with trade benefits and sovereignty concerns

items.question: The 2008 financial crisis revealed:
The Act of Union with Ireland (1801) resulted from:
options: B) Fear of French invasion through Ireland

items.question: Irish Home Rule's failure before 1914 stemmed from:
options: B) Ulster Protestant resistance and Conservative support

items.question: The Easter Rising (1916) transformed Irish nationalism by:
options: B) Creating martyrs and shifting opinion

items.question: Scottish nationalism's growth reflected:
options: B) Economic grievances and cultural revival

items.question: Devolution succeeded in 1997-1999 because:
options: B) Labour strategy and changed attitudes

items.question: The West Lothian Question asks:
options: B) Why Scottish MPs vote on English-only matters

items.question: The Good Friday Agreement succeeded through:
options: B) War exhaustion, international pressure, and inclusive framework

items.question: Scottish independence referendum (2014) failed because:
options: B) Economic uncertainty and unionist campaign

items.question: Brexit's impact on the Union includes:
The Democratic Deficit argument claims:
options: B) Scotland/Wales governed by parties they didn't elect

items.question: The Victorian "separate spheres" ideology:
options: B) Confined middle-class women to domestic roles
C) Applied to all classes equally

items.question: The British class system's persistence reflects:
options: B) Educational, cultural, and economic reproduction

items.question: The "permissive society" of the 1960s resulted from:
options: B) Affluence, education, and cultural change

items.question: Multiculturalism debates center on:
The BBC's creation reflected:
options: B) Public service ideals and national integration

items.question: The Establishment's power rested on:
options: B) Networks of education, class, and institutional positions

items.question: Post-war consensus included agreement on:
options: B) Welfare state, mixed economy, and full employment

items.question: Punk rock's significance went beyond music to:
options: B) Challenge post-war settlement and express alienation

items.question: The "Brain Drain" referred to:
options: B) Skilled emigration due to opportunities elsewhere

items.question: Cool Britannia represented:
options: B) Attempt to rebrand Britain as modern and creative

items.question: Brexit vote motivations included:
options: B) Sovereignty, immigration, and economic grievances

items.question: The 2008 financial crisis impacted Britain severely because:
options: B) Over-sized financial sector and housing bubble

items.question: Climate change policy tensions reflect:
options: B) Economic costs versus environmental necessity

items.question: The housing crisis stems from:
options: B) Supply constraints, financialization, and policy failures

items.question: NHS pressures include:
options: B) Aging population, technology costs, and political constraints

items.question: Social media's political impact includes:
options: B) Echo chambers, misinformation, and polarization

items.question: Regional inequality persists due to:
options: B) Deindustrialization, London-centricity, and policy failures

items.question: The gig economy reflects:
options: B) Flexibility demands and weakened labour protections

items.question: British identity questions arise from:
options: B) Devolution, immigration, and European integration

items.question: Post-truth politics emerged through:
options: B) Social media, distrust, and polarization
